DOC.HEAD: Earthquake Hits Remote Northern Quebec
Eds: LEADS thruout with new material and editing, slightly revising exact time and force of earthquake, including Northwest Territories. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A strong earthquake struck the Ungava Peninsula of northern Quebec, Baffin Island and the eastern part of the Northwest Territories on Christmas morning, but no damage or injuries were reported. The quake, which occurred at 9:24 a.m. EST, measured 6.2 on the Richter scale, said seismologist Robert North of the Ottawa office of the Geological Survey of Canada. ``An earthquake over 6 points is a serious earthquake and can cause severe damage in a populated area,'' North said. ``But fortunately the quake ... took place in a sparsely populated area which has no large buildings, so the effects should not cause any personal damage,'' he said. North said his office received a telephone call from the Inuit village of Igloolik to report the quake. Iqaluit, on Frobisher Bay in Baffin Island, also felt the temblor. Father Paul-Emile Tremblay, director of the Seismological Observatory at Montreal's Jean de Brebeuf College, said the epicenter was in the eastern part of the Northwest Territories and the quake was felt within a 620-mile radius. ``We have been noticing low-level tremors in that area for some time, so we were not surprised by the strong earthquake which occurred on Christmas morning,'' he said. The Richter scale is a gauge of the energy released by an earthquake, as measured by the ground motion recorded on a seismograph.
